Base directory for this skill: /root/Claude/claude-factory/.claude/skills/skill-creator

# Skill Creator

This skill provides guidance for creating effective skills.

## About Skills

Skills are modular, self-contained packages that extend Claude's capabilities by providing
specialized knowledge, workflows, and tools. Think of them as "onboarding guides" for specific
domains or tasks‚Äîthey transform Claude from a general-purpose agent into a specialized agent
equipped with procedural knowledge that no model can fully possess.

### What Skills Provide

1. Specialized workflows - Multi-step procedures for specific domains
2. Tool integrations - Instructions for working with specific file formats or APIs
3. Domain expertise - Company-specific knowledge, schemas, business logic
4. Bundled resources - Scripts, references, and assets for complex and repetitive tasks

### Anatomy of a Skill

Every skill consists of a required SKILL.md file and optional bundled resources:

```
skill-name/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SKILL.md (required)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ YAML frontmatter metadata (required)
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ name: (required)
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ description: (required)
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Markdown instructions (required)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Bundled Resources (optional)
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ scripts/          - Executable code (Python/Bash/etc.)
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ references/       - Documentation intended to be loaded into context as needed
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ assets/           - Files used in output (templates, icons, fonts, etc.)
```

#### SKILL.md (required)

**Metadata Quality:** The `name` and `description` in YAML frontmatter determine when Claude will use the skill. Be specific about what the skill does and when to use it. Use the third-person (e.g. "This skill should be used when..." instead of "Use this skill when...").

#### Bundled Resources (optional)

##### Scripts (`scripts/`)

Executable code (Python/Bash/etc.) for tasks that require deterministic reliability or are repeatedly rewritten.

- **When to include**: When the same code is being rewritten repeatedly or deterministic reliability is needed
- **Example**: `scripts/rotate_pdf.py` for PDF rotation tasks
- **Benefits**: Token efficient, deterministic, may be executed without loading into context
- **Note**: Scripts may still need to be read by Claude for patching or environment-specific adjustments

##### References (`references/`)

Documentation and reference material intended to be loaded as needed into context to inform Claude's process and thinking.

- **When to include**: For documentation that Claude should reference while working
- **Examples**: `references/finance.md` for financial schemas, `references/mnda.md` for company NDA template, `references/policies.md` for company policies, `references/api_docs.md` for API specifications
- **Use cases**: Database schemas, API documentation, domain knowledge, company policies, detailed workflow guides
- **Benefits**: Keeps SKILL.md lean, loaded only when Claude determines it's needed
- **Best practice**: If files are large (>10k words), include grep search patterns in SKILL.md
- **Avoid duplication**: Information should live in either SKILL.md or references files, not both. Prefer references files for detailed information unless it's truly core to the skill‚Äîthis keeps SKILL.md lean while making information discoverable without hogging the context window. Keep only essential procedural instructions and workflow guidance in SKILL.md; move detailed reference material, schemas, and examples to references files.

##### Assets (`assets/`)

Files not intended to be loaded into context, but rather used within the output Claude produces.

- **When to include**: When the skill needs files that will be used in the final output
- **Examples**: `assets/logo.png` for brand assets, `assets/slides.pptx` for PowerPoint templates, `assets/frontend-template/` for HTML/React boilerplate, `assets/font.ttf` for typography
- **Use cases**: Templates, images, icons, boilerplate code, fonts, sample documents that get copied or modified
- **Benefits**: Separates output resources from documentation, enables Claude to use files without loading them into context

### Progressive Disclosure Design Principle

Skills use a three-level loading system to manage context efficiently:

1. **Metadata (name + description)** - Always in context (~100 words)
2. **SKILL.md body** - When skill triggers (<5k words)
3. **Bundled resources** - As needed by Claude (Unlimited*)

*Unlimited because scripts can be executed without reading into context window.

## Skill Creation Process

To create a skill, follow the "Skill Creation Process" in order, skipping steps only if there is a clear reason why they are not applicable.

### Step 1: Understanding the Skill with Concrete Examples

Skip this step only when the skill's usage patterns are already clearly understood. It remains valuable even when working with an existing skill.

To create an effective skill, clearly understand concrete examples of how the skill will be used. This understanding can come from either direct user examples or generated examples that are validated with user feedback.

For example, when building an image-editor skill, relevant questions include:

- "What functionality should the image-editor skill support? Editing, rotating, anything else?"
- "Can you give some examples of how this skill would be used?"
- "I can imagine users asking for things like 'Remove the red-eye from this image' or 'Rotate this image'. Are there other ways you imagine this skill being used?"
- "What would a user say that should trigger this skill?"

To avoid overwhelming users, avoid asking too many questions in a single message. Start with the most important questions and follow up as needed for better effectiveness.

Conclude this step when there is a clear sense of the functionality the skill should support.

### Step 2: Planning the Reusable Skill Contents

To turn concrete examples into an effective skill, analyze each example by:

1. Considering how to execute on the example from scratch
2. Identifying what scripts, references, and assets would be helpful when executing these workflows repeatedly

Example: When building a `pdf-editor` skill to handle queries like "Help me rotate this PDF," the analysis shows:

1. Rotating a PDF requires re-writing the same code each time
2. A `scripts/rotate_pdf.py` script would be helpful to store in the skill

Example: When designing a `frontend-webapp-builder` skill for queries like "Build me a todo app" or "Build me a dashboard to track my steps," the analysis shows:

1. Writing a frontend webapp requires the same boilerplate HTML/React each time
2. An `assets/hello-world/` template containing the boilerplate HTML/React project files would be helpful to store in the skill

Example: When building a `big-query` skill to handle queries like "How many users have logged in today?" the analysis shows:

1. Querying BigQuery requires re-discovering the table schemas and relationships each time
2. A `references/schema.md` file documenting the table schemas would be helpful to store in the skill

To establish the skill's contents, analyze each concrete example to create a list of the reusable resources to include: scripts, references, and assets.

### Step 3: Initializing the Skill

At this point, it is time to actually create the skill.

Skip this step only if the skill being developed already exists, and iteration or packaging is needed. In this case, continue to the next step.

When creating a new skill from scratch, always run the `init_skill.py` script. The script conveniently generates a new template skill directory that automatically includes everything a skill requires, making the skill creation process much more efficient and reliable.

Usage:

```bash
scripts/init_skill.py <skill-name> --path <output-directory>
```

The script:

- Creates the skill directory at the specified path
- Generates a SKILL.md template with proper frontmatter and TODO placeholders
- Creates example resource directories: `scripts/`, `references/`, and `assets/`
- Adds example files in each directory that can be customized or deleted

After initialization, customize or remove the generated SKILL.md and example files as needed.

### Step 4: Edit the Skill

When editing the (newly-generated or existing) skill, remember that the skill is being created for another instance of Claude to use. Focus on including information that would be beneficial and non-obvious to Claude. Consider what procedural knowledge, domain-specific details, or reusable assets would help another Claude instance execute these tasks more effectively.

#### Start with Reusable Skill Contents

To begin implementation, start with the reusable resources identified above: `scripts/`, `references/`, and `assets/` files. Note that this step may require user input. For example, when implementing a `brand-guidelines` skill, the user may need to provide brand assets or templates to store in `assets/`, or documentation to store in `references/`.

Also, delete any example files and directories not needed for the skill. The initialization script creates example files in `scripts/`, `references/`, and `assets/` to demonstrate structure, but most skills won't need all of them.

#### Update SKILL.md

**Writing Style:** Write the entire skill using **imperative/infinitive form** (verb-first instructions), not second person. Use objective, instructional language (e.g., "To accomplish X, do Y" rather than "You should do X" or "If you need to do X"). This maintains consistency and clarity for AI consumption.

To complete SKILL.md, answer the following questions:

1. What is the purpose of the skill, in a few sentences?
2. When should the skill be used?
3. In practice, how should Claude use the skill? All reusable skill contents developed above should be referenced so that Claude knows how to use them.

### Step 5: Packaging a Skill

Once the skill is ready, it should be packaged into a distributable zip file that gets shared with the user. The packaging process automatically validates the skill first to ensure it meets all requirements:

```bash
scripts/package_skill.py <path/to/skill-folder>
```

Optional output directory specification:

```bash
scripts/package_skill.py <path/to/skill-folder> ./dist
```

The packaging script will:

1. **Validate** the skill automatically, checking:
   - YAML frontmatter format and required fields
   - Skill naming conventions and directory structure
   - Description completeness and quality
   - File organization and resource references

2. **Package** the skill if validation passes, creating a zip file named after the skill (e.g., `my-skill.zip`) that includes all files and maintains the proper directory structure for distribution.

If validation fails, the script will report the errors and exit without creating a package. Fix any validation errors and run the packaging command again.

### Step 6: Iterate

After testing the skill, users may request improvements. Often this happens right after using the skill, with fresh context of how the skill performed.

**Iteration workflow:**
1. Use the skill on real tasks
2. Notice struggles or inefficiencies
3. Identify how SKILL.md or bundled resources should be updated
4. Implement changes and test again

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Generate a detailed thesis timeline with weekly tasks from current date to deadline.
Calculates workdays (Monday-Friday) and distributes work evenly.
"""

import argparse
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from typing import List, Dict

def get_workdays(start_date: datetime, end_date: datetime) -> int:
    """Calculate number of weekdays (Mon-Fri) between two dates."""
    workdays = 0
    current = start_date
    while current <= end_date:
        if current.weekday() < 5:  # Monday = 0, Friday = 4
            workdays += 1
        current += timedelta(days=1)
    return workdays

def generate_weekly_breakdown(
    start_date: datetime,
    end_date: datetime,
    total_pages: int,
    hours_per_day: float,
    phases: List[str]
) -> List[Dict]:
    """Generate weekly task breakdown."""

    total_workdays = get_workdays(start_date, end_date)
    total_weeks = (end_date - start_date).days / 7

    # Calculate work distribution
    pages_per_week = total_pages / total_weeks
    hours_per_week = hours_per_day * 5  # 5 workdays

    weeks = []
    current_date = start_date
    week_num = 1
    cumulative_pages = 0

    while current_date < end_date:
        week_end = min(current_date + timedelta(days=6), end_date)
        workdays_in_week = get_workdays(current_date, week_end)

        # Determine phase based on week number
        phase_index = min(int((week_num - 1) / (total_weeks / len(phases))), len(phases) - 1)
        current_phase = phases[phase_index]

        # Calculate targets
        target_pages = pages_per_week
        cumulative_pages += target_pages

        weeks.append({
            'week_num': week_num,
            'start_date': current_date.strftime('%Y-%m-%d'),
            'end_date': week_end.strftime('%Y-%m-%d'),
            'workdays': workdays_in_week,
            'phase': current_phase,
            'target_pages': round(target_pages, 1),
            'cumulative_pages': round(cumulative_pages, 1),
            'hours_available': workdays_in_week * hours_per_day
        })

        current_date = week_end + timedelta(days=1)
        week_num += 1

    return weeks

def format_markdown_timeline(
    weeks: List[Dict],
    total_pages: int,
    deadline: str,
    hours_per_day: float
) -> str:
    """Format timeline as markdown."""

    md = f"""# Bachelor Thesis Timeline

**Deadline:** {deadline}
**Target:** {total_pages} pages
**Work Schedule:** Monday-Friday, {hours_per_day} hours/day

---

## Weekly Breakdown

"""

    for week in weeks:
        md += f"""### Week {week['week_num']}: {week['start_date']} to {week['end_date']}
**Phase:** {week['phase']}
**Workdays Available:** {week['workdays']} days ({week['hours_available']:.0f} hours)
**Target Pages:** {week['target_pages']} pages (Cumulative: {week['cumulative_pages']}/{total_pages})

**Tasks:**
- [ ] TASK_PLACEHOLDER üìÖ {week['start_date']}

---

"""

    return md

def main():
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(
        description='Generate thesis timeline with weekly breakdown'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--start-date',
        type=str,
        default=datetime.now().strftime('%Y-%m-%d'),
        help='Start date (YYYY-MM-DD)'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--deadline',
        type=str,
        required=True,
        help='Deadline date (YYYY-MM-DD)'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--pages',
        type=int,
        default=50,
        help='Target page count'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--hours-per-day',
        type=float,
        default=4.5,
        help='Hours available per workday'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--phases',
        type=str,
        nargs='+',
        default=['Research & Literature Review', 'Experimentation & Implementation', 'Writing & Analysis', 'Revision & Finalization'],
        help='Thesis phases'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--output',
        type=str,
        help='Output file path (optional, prints to stdout if not provided)'
    )

    args = parser.parse_args()

    # Parse dates
    start_date = datetime.strptime(args.start_date, '%Y-%m-%d')
    end_date = datetime.strptime(args.deadline, '%Y-%m-%d')

    # Validate
    if end_date <= start_date:
        print("Error: Deadline must be after start date")
        return 1

    # Generate timeline
    weeks = generate_weekly_breakdown(
        start_date,
        end_date,
        args.pages,
        args.hours_per_day,
        args.phases
    )

    # Format output
    timeline = format_markdown_timeline(
        weeks,
        args.pages,
        args.deadline,
        args.hours_per_day
    )

    # Output
    if args.output:
        with open(args.output, 'w') as f:
            f.write(timeline)
        print(f"Timeline generated: {args.output}")
    else:
        print(timeline)

    # Print summary
    total_workdays = get_workdays(start_date, end_date)
    total_hours = total_workdays * args.hours_per_day
    print(f"\nüìä Summary:", file=__import__('sys').stderr)
    print(f"  Total weeks: {len(weeks)}", file=__import__('sys').stderr)
    print(f"  Total workdays: {total_workdays}", file=__import__('sys').stderr)
    print(f"  Total hours available: {total_hours:.0f}", file=__import__('sys').stderr)
    print(f"  Pages per week: {args.pages / len(weeks):.1f}", file=__import__('sys').stderr)

    return 0

if __name__ == '__main__':
    exit(main())

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Track thesis writing progress and calculate remaining work.
"""

import argparse
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

def calculate_progress(
    pages_completed: int,
    total_pages: int,
    current_date: datetime,
    deadline: datetime,
    hours_per_day: float
) -> dict:
    """Calculate progress metrics and recommendations."""

    # Calculate time remaining
    days_remaining = (deadline - current_date).days

    # Count workdays remaining (Mon-Fri only)
    workdays_remaining = 0
    temp_date = current_date
    while temp_date < deadline:
        if temp_date.weekday() < 5:  # Monday = 0, Friday = 4
            workdays_remaining += 1
        temp_date += timedelta(days=1)

    # Calculate progress
    pages_remaining = total_pages - pages_completed
    progress_percent = (pages_completed / total_pages) * 100

    # Calculate required pace
    hours_remaining = workdays_remaining * hours_per_day
    pages_per_day_required = pages_remaining / workdays_remaining if workdays_remaining > 0 else 0
    pages_per_hour_required = pages_remaining / hours_remaining if hours_remaining > 0 else 0

    # Calculate expected progress (linear)
    total_days = (deadline - datetime.now()).days + (datetime.now() - current_date).days
    total_workdays = sum(
        1 for d in range(total_days)
        if (datetime.now() - timedelta(days=total_days) + timedelta(days=d)).weekday() < 5
    )
    days_passed = (current_date - (deadline - timedelta(days=total_days))).days
    workdays_passed = sum(
        1 for d in range(days_passed)
        if (deadline - timedelta(days=total_days) + timedelta(days=d)).weekday() < 5
    )
    expected_pages = (workdays_passed / total_workdays) * total_pages if total_workdays > 0 else 0

    # Status assessment
    if pages_completed >= expected_pages:
        status = "On Track" if pages_completed >= expected_pages * 0.95 else "Slightly Behind"
    else:
        if pages_completed < expected_pages * 0.8:
            status = "Significantly Behind"
        else:
            status = "Behind Schedule"

    return {
        'pages_completed': pages_completed,
        'pages_remaining': pages_remaining,
        'total_pages': total_pages,
        'progress_percent': progress_percent,
        'days_remaining': days_remaining,
        'workdays_remaining': workdays_remaining,
        'hours_remaining': hours_remaining,
        'pages_per_day_required': pages_per_day_required,
        'pages_per_hour_required': pages_per_hour_required,
        'expected_pages': expected_pages,
        'status': status
    }

def format_progress_report(metrics: dict) -> str:
    """Format progress metrics as readable report."""

    report = f"""# Thesis Progress Report

## Current Status: {metrics['status']}

### Progress Overview
- **Pages Completed:** {metrics['pages_completed']}/{metrics['total_pages']} ({metrics['progress_percent']:.1f}%)
- **Pages Remaining:** {metrics['pages_remaining']} pages
- **Expected Progress:** {metrics['expected_pages']:.1f} pages

### Time Remaining
- **Days Until Deadline:** {metrics['days_remaining']} days
- **Workdays Remaining:** {metrics['workdays_remaining']} workdays (Mon-Fri)
- **Hours Available:** {metrics['hours_remaining']:.0f} hours

### Required Pace
- **Pages per Workday:** {metrics['pages_per_day_required']:.1f} pages/day
- **Pages per Hour:** {metrics['pages_per_hour_required']:.2f} pages/hour

"""

    # Add recommendations
    if metrics['status'] == "Significantly Behind":
        report += """### ‚ö†Ô∏è Action Required
You are significantly behind schedule. Consider:
- Increasing daily work hours if possible
- Focusing on essential sections first
- Simplifying experimental scope
- Discussing timeline with advisor

"""
    elif metrics['status'] == "Behind Schedule":
        report += """### ‚ö†Ô∏è Recommendations
You are behind schedule. Consider:
- Reviewing and optimizing daily schedule
- Eliminating non-essential tasks
- Focusing on high-priority sections

"""
    elif metrics['status'] == "On Track":
        report += """### ‚úÖ You're On Track!
Maintain your current pace. Continue to:
- Follow your weekly plan
- Review and revise completed sections
- Stay consistent with daily work hours

"""

    return report

def main():
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(
        description='Track thesis writing progress'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--pages-completed',
        type=int,
        required=True,
        help='Number of pages completed so far'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--total-pages',
        type=int,
        default=50,
        help='Target page count'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--deadline',
        type=str,
        required=True,
        help='Deadline date (YYYY-MM-DD)'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--hours-per-day',
        type=float,
        default=4.5,
        help='Hours available per workday'
    )
    parser.add_argument(
        '--output',
        type=str,
        help='Output file path (optional)'
    )

    args = parser.parse_args()

    # Parse deadline
    deadline = datetime.strptime(args.deadline, '%Y-%m-%d')
    current_date = datetime.now()

    # Calculate metrics
    metrics = calculate_progress(
        args.pages_completed,
        args.total_pages,
        current_date,
        deadline,
        args.hours_per_day
    )

    # Format report
    report = format_progress_report(metrics)

    # Output
    if args.output:
        with open(args.output, 'w') as f:
            f.write(report)
        print(f"Progress report saved: {args.output}")
    else:
        print(report)

    return 0

if __name__ == '__main__':
    exit(main())

# Computer Science Bachelor Thesis Structure Template

## Typical Page Distribution (50 pages total)

### Front Matter (2-3 pages)
- Title page
- Abstract (1 page)
- Table of contents
- List of figures/tables

### 1. Introduction (4-6 pages)
- **Motivation:** Why is this topic important?
- **Problem Statement:** What specific problem are you addressing?
- **Research Questions:** What are you trying to answer?
- **Objectives:** What will you accomplish?
- **Scope:** What is included/excluded?
- **Structure:** Overview of the thesis organization

### 2. Background & Related Work (8-12 pages)
- **Theoretical Background:** Key concepts and theories
- **Literature Review:** What has been done before?
- **Related Technologies/Methods:** Tools and approaches used
- **Gap Analysis:** What's missing in current work?
- **Your Contribution:** How does your work address the gap?

### 3. Methodology (6-8 pages)
- **Approach:** Overall strategy for addressing the research questions
- **System Design/Architecture:** High-level design of your solution
- **Implementation Details:** Key technical decisions
- **Tools & Technologies:** Software, libraries, frameworks used
- **Experimental Setup:** How you'll test/evaluate your work
- **Data Collection:** What data you'll gather and how

### 4. Implementation (8-10 pages)
- **System Overview:** Architecture diagrams and description
- **Key Components:** Detailed implementation of main features
- **Algorithms:** Important algorithms with pseudocode/flowcharts
- **Challenges & Solutions:** Problems encountered and how you solved them
- **Code Samples:** Relevant code snippets (not everything!)
- **Testing Approach:** Unit tests, integration tests, etc.

### 5. Experiments & Results (8-10 pages)
- **Experimental Design:** What experiments you ran and why
- **Datasets:** Description of data used
- **Evaluation Metrics:** How you measure success
- **Results:** Present findings with tables, graphs, charts
- **Analysis:** Interpretation of results
- **Comparison:** How do results compare to existing solutions?

### 6. Discussion (4-6 pages)
- **Summary of Findings:** Main takeaways
- **Interpretation:** What do the results mean?
- **Strengths:** What worked well?
- **Limitations:** What are the constraints and weaknesses?
- **Implications:** What does this mean for the field?
- **Lessons Learned:** What did you learn during the process?

### 7. Conclusion (2-3 pages)
- **Summary:** Brief recap of the entire thesis
- **Contributions:** What did you accomplish?
- **Research Questions Answered:** Direct answers to RQs from introduction
- **Future Work:** What could be done next?

### Back Matter (3-4 pages)
- References/Bibliography
- Appendices (optional: additional code, data, detailed tables)

---

## Writing Guidelines

### Academic Writing Style
- **Formal tone:** Avoid colloquialisms and first-person (use "we" if acceptable)
- **Precise language:** Be specific and technical
- **Active voice:** Prefer "We implement X" over "X is implemented"
- **Clear structure:** Use headings, subheadings, and transitions

### Page Estimation Rules
- **Figures/Tables:** Each full-page figure counts as 0.5 pages of writing
- **Code samples:** Keep to minimum, use appendices for lengthy code
- **References:** Count as part of back matter, not main content

### CS-Specific Tips
- Include architecture diagrams and flowcharts
- Show algorithm complexity analysis where relevant
- Provide performance benchmarks and comparisons
- Document all dependencies and system requirements
- Include screenshots of working system where appropriate
- Reference all libraries, frameworks, and external code used

### Citation Management
- Use consistent citation style (IEEE, ACM, APA, etc.)
- Cite all sources: papers, books, websites, libraries
- Keep a reference manager (Zotero, Mendeley, BibTeX)

---

## Common Pitfalls to Avoid

1. **Too much implementation detail:** Focus on key insights, not line-by-line code
2. **Insufficient evaluation:** Need quantitative and qualitative results
3. **Missing related work:** Must show awareness of existing research
4. **Weak conclusion:** Don't just repeat the introduction
5. **No critical analysis:** Discuss limitations and alternative approaches
6. **Poor time management:** Implementation takes longer than expected
7. **Scope creep:** Stay focused on defined research questions

# Weekly Thesis Planning Checklist

Use this checklist each week to plan and track your thesis progress.

## Weekly Planning Template

- [ ] Key concepts added to thesis document
- [ ] References added to bibliography

- [ ] Code written and tested

## Quick Reference: Time Management

### Typical 4-5 Hour Workday Breakdown

**Morning Block (2-2.5 hours):**
- Deep work: writing, coding, analysis
- Focus on most challenging tasks
- Minimize distractions

**Break (15-30 minutes)**

**Afternoon Block (2-2.5 hours):**
- Research, reading, literature review
- Experiments, testing
- Revision and editing

### Weekly Time Allocation (20-25 hours/week)

| Activity | Hours/Week | Percentage |
|----------|------------|------------|
| Writing | 8-10 | 40% |
| Research/Reading | 4-5 | 20% |
| Implementation/Experiments | 6-8 | 30% |
| Revision/Admin | 2-2 | 10% |

### Red Flags üö©

- [ ] Missed 2+ days of work this week
- [ ] No progress on weekly goal
- [ ] Behind on page target by 5+ pages
- [ ] Blocked on issue for more than 3 days
- [ ] No advisor communication in 2+ weeks

**If any red flags checked:** Schedule time to address immediately!

---

**Hours Worked:** _____ hours
**Pages Written:** _____ pages
**Overall Assessment:** [On Track / Minor Adjustments Needed / Major Concerns]

**Action Items for Next Week:**

- Example: DOCX skill with "Workflow Decision Tree" ‚Üí "Reading" ‚Üí "Creating" ‚Üí "Editing"
- Structure: ## Overview ‚Üí ## Workflow Decision Tree ‚Üí ## Step 1 ‚Üí ## Step 2...

- Works well when the skill offers different operations/capabilities
- Example: PDF skill with "Quick Start" ‚Üí "Merge PDFs" ‚Üí "Split PDFs" ‚Üí "Extract Text"
- Structure: ## Overview ‚Üí ## Quick Start ‚Üí ## Task Category 1 ‚Üí ## Task Category 2...

- Works well for brand guidelines, coding standards, or requirements
- Example: Brand styling with "Brand Guidelines" ‚Üí "Colors" ‚Üí "Typography" ‚Üí "Features"
- Structure: ## Overview ‚Üí ## Guidelines ‚Üí ## Specifications ‚Üí ## Usage...

- Works well when the skill provides multiple interrelated features
- Example: Product Management with "Core Capabilities" ‚Üí numbered capability list
- Structure: ## Overview ‚Üí ## Core Capabilities ‚Üí ### 1. Feature ‚Üí ### 2. Feature...

## Resources

This skill includes example resource directories that demonstrate how to organize different types of bundled resources:

### scripts/
Executable code (Python/Bash/etc.) that can be run directly to perform specific operations.

**Examples from other skills:**
- PDF skill: `fill_fillable_fields.py`, `extract_form_field_info.py` - utilities for PDF manipulation
- DOCX skill: `document.py`, `utilities.py` - Python modules for document processing

**Appropriate for:** Python scripts, shell scripts, or any executable code that performs automation, data processing, or specific operations.

**Note:** Scripts may be executed without loading into context, but can still be read by Claude for patching or environment adjustments.

### references/
Documentation and reference material intended to be loaded into context to inform Claude's process and thinking.

**Examples from other skills:**
- Product management: `communication.md`, `context_building.md` - detailed workflow guides
- BigQuery: API reference documentation and query examples
- Finance: Schema documentation, company policies

**Appropriate for:** In-depth documentation, API references, database schemas, comprehensive guides, or any detailed information that Claude should reference while working.

### assets/
Files not intended to be loaded into context, but rather used within the output Claude produces.

**Examples from other skills:**
- Brand styling: PowerPoint template files (.pptx), logo files
- Frontend builder: HTML/React boilerplate project directories
- Typography: Font files (.ttf, .woff2)

---
name: bachelor-thesis-planner
description: This skill should be used when planning and managing a Bachelor thesis project. Use when users need to create timelines, track writing progress, organize research phases, or structure their thesis work. Particularly valuable for CS/engineering theses with implementation and experimental components. Handles deadline-driven planning with workday calculations (Monday-Friday schedules).
---

# Bachelor Thesis Planner

## Overview

Plan, organize, and track Bachelor thesis projects from start to deadline. Generate detailed weekly timelines, track writing progress against page targets, and manage the complete thesis lifecycle including research, implementation, experimentation, and writing phases.

## When to Use This Skill

Activate this skill when users request:
- "Help me plan my Bachelor thesis"
- "Create a timeline for my thesis (deadline: [date])"
- "Track my thesis progress"
- "I need to write [X] pages by [date]"
- "Plan my thesis research and writing schedule"
- "How am I doing on my thesis? I've written [X] pages"

## Core Capabilities

### 1. Timeline Generation

Generate comprehensive weekly timelines from current date to deadline with automatic workday calculation (Monday-Friday only).

**Usage:**
```bash
python scripts/generate_timeline.py \
  --deadline 2025-01-15 \
  --pages 50 \
  --hours-per-day 4.5 \
  --output timeline.md
```

**Parameters:**
- `--deadline`: Thesis submission deadline (YYYY-MM-DD)
- `--pages`: Target page count (default: 50)
- `--hours-per-day`: Available work hours per workday (default: 4.5)
- `--phases`: Custom phase names (optional)
- `--output`: Output file path (optional, prints to stdout if omitted)

**Output includes:**
- Week-by-week breakdown with dates
- Current thesis phase (Research, Implementation, Writing, Revision)
- Workdays and hours available per week
- Target pages per week with cumulative tracking
- Task placeholders in format: `- [ ] TASK üìÖ YYYY-MM-DD`

**Default phases:**
1. Research & Literature Review
2. Experimentation & Implementation
3. Writing & Analysis
4. Revision & Finalization

To customize phases, use:
```bash
--phases "Phase 1 Name" "Phase 2 Name" "Phase 3 Name"
```

### 2. Progress Tracking

Track actual progress against planned timeline and calculate required pace adjustments.

**Usage:**
```bash
python scripts/track_progress.py \
  --pages-completed 25 \
  --total-pages 50 \
  --deadline 2025-01-15 \
  --hours-per-day 4.5 \
  --output progress_report.md
```

**Parameters:**
- `--pages-completed`: Pages written so far
- `--total-pages`: Target page count (default: 50)
- `--deadline`: Thesis submission deadline (YYYY-MM-DD)
- `--hours-per-day`: Available work hours per workday (default: 4.5)
- `--output`: Output file path (optional)

**Output includes:**
- Progress percentage and status assessment
- Pages remaining and time remaining
- Required pages per day/hour to finish on time
- Comparison to expected linear progress
- Status: "On Track", "Slightly Behind", "Behind Schedule", or "Significantly Behind"
- Actionable recommendations based on status

### 3. Thesis Structure Guidance

Refer to `references/thesis_structure_template.md` for:
- Complete CS thesis structure (50+ pages)
- Chapter-by-chapter page recommendations
- Content guidelines for each section
- Academic writing tips and common pitfalls
- Citation and formatting guidance

**To use:**
```bash
cat references/thesis_structure_template.md
```

Load this reference when users ask:
- "How should I structure my thesis?"
- "How many pages for each chapter?"
- "What goes in the methodology section?"
- "Help me outline my thesis"

### 4. Weekly Planning Templates

Use `references/weekly_checklist.md` for weekly planning sessions:
- Complete weekly checklist template
- Daily task breakdown (Monday-Friday)
- Progress tracking checkboxes
- Time management guidelines
- Red flags and warning signs

**To use:**
Copy the template and customize for each week:
```bash
cat references/weekly_checklist.md
```

### 5. Daily Work Logs

Use `assets/daily_log_template.md` for daily tracking:
- Daily goals and task lists
- Hours worked and accomplishments
- Notes, insights, and blockers
- Next day planning

**To use:**
Copy template for each workday:
```bash
cp assets/daily_log_template.md daily_log_[DATE].md
```

## Typical Workflow

### Initial Planning Session

When a user requests thesis planning:

1. **Gather requirements:**
   - Deadline date
   - Target page count
   - Daily available hours (Monday-Friday)
   - Thesis topic/field
   - Current outline status

2. **Generate timeline:**
   ```bash
   python scripts/generate_timeline.py \
     --deadline [USER_DEADLINE] \
     --pages [TARGET_PAGES] \
     --hours-per-day [DAILY_HOURS] \
     --output thesis_timeline.md
   ```

3. **Customize timeline:**
   - Open generated `thesis_timeline.md`
   - Replace `TASK_PLACEHOLDER` entries with specific tasks based on:
     - User's thesis outline
     - Current phase (research/implementation/writing)
     - `references/thesis_structure_template.md` chapter breakdown

4. **Provide structure guidance:**
   - Share relevant sections from `references/thesis_structure_template.md`
   - Help break down chapters into weekly targets

### Weekly Check-ins

When user reports progress:

1. **Run progress tracker:**
   ```bash
   python scripts/track_progress.py \
     --pages-completed [CURRENT_PAGES] \
     --deadline [USER_DEADLINE] \
     --total-pages [TARGET_PAGES] \
     --hours-per-day [DAILY_HOURS]
   ```

2. **Review status:**
   - Analyze progress report output
   - Discuss recommendations if behind schedule
   - Adjust timeline if needed

3. **Plan next week:**
   - Copy `references/weekly_checklist.md` template
   - Fill in specific tasks for upcoming week
   - Set realistic page targets based on progress tracker

### Phase Transitions

When moving between thesis phases:

1. **Review completed phase:**
   - Check off completed tasks
   - Document lessons learned

2. **Prepare next phase:**
   - Regenerate timeline if needed (updated `--phases` parameter)
   - Update weekly focus in checklist
   - Adjust daily task types (research ‚Üí writing ‚Üí revision)

## Task Format Convention

All tasks in timelines and checklists use this format:
```
- [ ] TASK_DESCRIPTION üìÖ YYYY-MM-DD
```

**Example:**
```
- [ ] Read 3 papers on neural networks üìÖ 2025-11-08
- [ ] Implement baseline model üìÖ 2025-11-09
- [ ] Write methodology section draft üìÖ 2025-11-10
```

When customizing timelines, replace `TASK_PLACEHOLDER` with specific, actionable tasks following this format.

## Time Management Guidelines

### Typical 4-5 Hour Workday Structure

**Morning Block (2-2.5 hours):**
- Deep work: writing, coding, analysis
- Most challenging tasks
- Minimize distractions

**Break (15-30 minutes)**

**Afternoon Block (2-2.5 hours):**
- Research, reading, literature review
- Experiments, testing, data collection
- Revision and editing

### Weekly Time Distribution (20-25 hours)

| Activity | Hours/Week | Percentage |
|----------|------------|------------|
| Writing | 8-10 | 40% |
| Research/Reading | 4-5 | 20% |
| Implementation/Experiments | 6-8 | 30% |
| Revision/Admin | 2-2 | 10% |

Adjust based on current phase:
- **Research phase:** 50% research, 30% writing, 20% implementation
- **Implementation phase:** 50% implementation, 30% writing, 20% research
- **Writing phase:** 70% writing, 20% revision, 10% research
- **Revision phase:** 80% revision, 20% final writing

## Common Scenarios

### Scenario: User significantly behind schedule

**When progress tracker shows "Significantly Behind":**

1. Run the progress tracker to quantify the gap
2. Discuss realistic options:
   - Increase daily hours (if possible)
   - Simplify scope (reduce experimental work)
   - Prioritize essential sections
   - Discuss with thesis advisor
3. Create recovery plan:
   - Regenerate timeline with adjusted parameters
   - Focus on high-value sections first
   - Cut non-essential content

### Scenario: User ahead of schedule

**When progress tracker shows "On Track" with buffer:**

1. Celebrate the progress
2. Suggest using buffer time for:
   - More thorough literature review
   - Additional experiments/features
   - Earlier revision passes
   - Building presentation materials
3. Consider moving deadline internally earlier for stress reduction

### Scenario: User needs to restructure thesis

**When outline changes significantly:**

1. Review `references/thesis_structure_template.md` together
2. Create new chapter breakdown with page targets
3. Regenerate timeline if deadline/pages changed
4. Update weekly tasks to match new structure
5. Adjust progress tracking baseline

## Best Practices

1. **Generate timeline early:** Create the timeline at project start, even if approximate
2. **Track weekly:** Run progress tracker every Friday to catch issues early
3. **Be realistic:** Use actual available hours, account for other commitments
4. **Update regularly:** Regenerate timeline when circumstances change
5. **Break down tasks:** Convert abstract goals ("write chapter 3") into concrete daily tasks
6. **Use templates:** Copy daily/weekly templates consistently for habit formation
7. **Review structure:** Consult thesis structure template when planning each chapter
8. **Buffer time:** Plan to finish 3-5 days before actual deadline for emergency buffer

## Troubleshooting

**Timeline seems too aggressive:**
- Reduce `--hours-per-day` to realistic value
- Increase `--pages` estimate if current target too ambitious
- Check if deadline is correct

**Tasks not fitting in weekly schedule:**
- Break tasks into smaller units
- Prioritize and move non-essential tasks
- Consider if scope is too large

**Progress tracker showing unexpected status:**
- Verify `--pages-completed` count is accurate
- Check page counting methodology (full pages? half pages?)
- Ensure deadline date is correct

**Generated timeline has wrong phase names:**
- Use `--phases` parameter to customize phase names
- Order phases chronologically
- Number of phases is flexible (3-5 recommended)

## Resources Summary

**Scripts:**
- `scripts/generate_timeline.py` - Generate weekly timeline with workday calculations
- `scripts/track_progress.py` - Calculate progress metrics and status assessment

**References:**
- `references/thesis_structure_template.md` - Complete CS thesis structure guide (50+ pages)
- `references/weekly_checklist.md` - Weekly planning template with time management tips

**Assets:**
- `assets/daily_log_template.md` - Daily work log template for tracking daily progress

All scripts support `--help` flag for detailed usage information.

Skill Contents:


Scripts (Automated Tools):


    

  • generate_timeline.py - Generates week-by-week timeline from today until Jan 15, 2025
    

      

    • Calculates workdays (Monday-Friday only)
      • 

    • Distributes 50 pages across available weeks
      • 

    • Creates 4 phases: Research, Implementation, Writing, Revision
      • 

    • Outputs weekly tasks in your requested format: - [ ] TASK üìÖ YYYY-MM-DD
      • 

    

    • 

  • track_progress.py - Tracks your writing progress
    

      

    • Shows pages completed vs target
      • 

    • Calculates required pace (pages/day, pages/hour)
      • 

    • Provides status: "On Track", "Behind Schedule", etc.
      • 

    • Gives actionable recommendations
      • 

    

    • 



References (Guidance Documents):


    

  • thesis_structure_template.md - Complete CS thesis structure guide
    

      

    • 50-page breakdown by chapter
      • 

    • Content guidelines for each section
      • 

    • Academic writing tips
      • 

    • Common pitfalls to avoid
      • 

    

    • 

  • weekly_checklist.md - Weekly planning template
    

      

    • Daily task breakdown (Mon-Fri)
      • 

    • Time management guidelines (4-5 hours/day structure)
      • 

    • Progress tracking checkboxes
      • 

    • Red flag warnings
      • 

    

    • 



Assets (Templates):


    

  • daily_log_template.md - Daily work tracking template
      

    • Daily goals and accomplishments
      • 

    • Hours worked
      • 

    • Notes and blockers
      • 

    

    • 



How to Use


Once installed, Claude will automatically use this skill when you say:


    

  • "Help me plan my Bachelor thesis"
    • 

  • "Create a timeline for my thesis"
    • 

  • "Track my progress - I've written 15 pages"
    • 



The skill handles all your requirements:


    

  • 50-page target
    • 

  • Jan 15, 2025 deadline
    • 

  • Monday-Friday work schedule (4-5 hours/day)
    • 

  • CS/Engineering thesis with research, implementation, and experimentation
    • 

  • Weekly task format with dates
    •
